results.title: Reproductive cessation in female mammals.

theories.name: Evolutionary theory of reproductive senescence via weakened late-life selection

key_concepts.concept: Decline in reproductive performance due to senescence
key_concepts.description: Reproductive cessation in female mammals, including menopause, results from physiological senescence, such as the depletion of oocytes and breakdown of neural pacemakers controlling reproduction.

key_concepts.concept: Weak natural selection at advanced ages
key_concepts.description: Because many individuals die from extrinsic causes before old age, natural selection is too weak at late ages to prevent the accumulation of deleterious alleles or pleiotropic effects that reduce reproductive capacity.

key_concepts.concept: Non-adaptive by-product rather than evolutionary adaptation
key_concepts.description: The abrupt reproductive decline is not an adaptation to enhance inclusive fitness (e.g., grandmother hypothesis), but rather a consequence of life-history patterns and senescence.

key_concepts.concept: Fitness consequences of reproductive cessation are minimal
key_concepts.description: Modeling shows that maintaining fertility at advanced ages would have negligible impact on population growth, supporting the idea that selection pressure to maintain late-life reproduction is minimal.

key_concepts.concept: Infant dependency shapes timing of reproductive senescence
key_concepts.description: The lag between reproductive and somatic senescence is influenced by the duration of infant dependency, with longer dependency favoring longer somatic survival post-reproductive cessation.

theories.evidence: Field data from olive baboons and African lions showing age-specific mortality and maternity rates, reproductive cycle changes, infant survival, and kin-directed behavior; statistical analyses of survival and reproduction costs; population growth modeling comparing observed and hypothetical non-menopausal cohorts.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets all criteria: explains why reproductive aging occurs broadly in female mammals via evolutionary weakening of selection at late ages; proposes causal mechanisms (genetic pleiotropy, mutation accumulation, physiological senescence); generalizable beyond specific species; addresses organism-level aging process.

results.title: Gerontology. Mutation, variation and the evolution of ageing.

theories.name: Mutation Accumulation Theory of Aging

key_concepts.concept: Late-acting deleterious mutations
key_concepts.description: Mutations that have harmful effects expressed late in life accumulate in populations because natural selection against them is weak, as many carriers die from other causes before these mutations manifest.

key_concepts.concept: Mutation-selection balance
key_concepts.description: A balance is reached where deleterious mutations with late-life effects persist at higher frequencies than those expressed earlier, leading to aging as a consequence of accumulated genetic damage.

key_concepts.concept: Increased genetic variation in late-life mortality
key_concepts.description: The theory predicts greater genetic variation in mortality rates at older ages due to the accumulation of these late-acting mutations.

theories.evidence: Experiments with Drosophila showing increased additive genetic effects on mortality rates at late ages; breeding designs isolating chromosome effects on survival; indirect evidence from selection experiments altering late-life traits.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets all criteria: explains aging as a fundamental process via accumulation of mutations affecting late life, proposes causal mechanisms, and addresses aging broadly at organism level.

theories.name: Antagonistic Pleiotropy Theory of Aging

key_concepts.concept: Pleiotropic mutations with early-life benefits and late-life costs
key_concepts.description: Mutations that confer advantages such as increased fertility or growth early in life but have deleterious effects later are favored by natural selection due to stronger selection pressure on early-life traits.

key_concepts.concept: Trade-off between reproduction and somatic maintenance
key_concepts.description: Organisms may allocate resources to early reproduction at the expense of somatic repair, leading to aging as a byproduct of optimizing life history traits.

theories.evidence: Artificial selection experiments in Drosophila where lines selected for late reproduction showed increased lifespan but reduced early fertility or pre-adult survival, consistent with pleiotropic trade-offs.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets all criteria: provides a general causal explanation for aging based on evolutionary trade-offs, applicable organism-wide, and supported by experimental data.

results.title: Greater physical fitness (Vo2Max) in healthy older adults associated with increased integrity of the Locus Coeruleus-Noradrenergic system.

theories.name: Noradrenergic Theory of Cognitive Reserve

key_concepts.concept: Upregulation of the Locus Coeruleus-Noradrenergic (LC-NA) System
key_concepts.description: The theory proposes that continuous activation and integrity of the LC-NA system across the lifespan is a key neurobiological component for building cognitive reserve and resilience to neurodegeneration. The LC-NA system's neuroprotective role helps maintain brain health and cognitive function despite neuropathological insults.

key_concepts.concept: Neuroprotective Role of Noradrenaline (NA)
key_concepts.description: Noradrenaline released by the LC has anti-oxidative and anti-inflammatory properties, promotes neurogenesis and synaptogenesis via increasing brain-derived neurotrophic factor (BDNF), and reduces biomarkers of neurodegeneration, thereby protecting brain tissue and supporting cognitive reserve.

key_concepts.concept: Physical Activity as a Modulator of LC-NA System
key_concepts.description: Physical activity, especially intense exercise increasing oxygen demand (measured by Vo2max), elicits enhanced NA synthesis and release, which may upregulate and maintain LC-NA system integrity, thus contributing to cognitive reserve and resilience against neurodegenerative diseases.

key_concepts.concept: LC-NA System Integrity as a Biomarker of Brain Maintenance
key_concepts.description: MRI signal intensity of the LC is used as a proxy for LC integrity, which correlates with physical fitness (Vo2max), biological brain maintenance (BrainPAD), and higher-order cognitive control, supporting the theory that LC-NA system health underpins cognitive reserve.

theories.evidence: The study presents empirical evidence from voxel-based morphometry (VBM) analyses of 41 healthy older adults showing a significant positive association between Vo2max and LC MRI signal intensity. Control analyses with other neuromodulatory systems showed weaker associations. Additional correlations with BrainPAD and cognitive control measures support the theory. The paper also cites extensive prior literature on NA's neuroprotective effects, physical activity-induced NA release, and LC degeneration in dementia.
theories.criteria_reasoning: The theory meets all criteria: it provides a generalizable causal explanation for aging-related cognitive decline via LC-NA system integrity; it addresses aging broadly through neurodegeneration and cognitive reserve; it proposes mechanisms (NA neuroprotection, inflammation reduction, BDNF promotion) underlying aging processes; and it is supported by empirical data linking physical fitness to LC integrity and cognitive outcomes.

results.title: Amino acid restriction, aging, and longevity: an update.

theories.name: Amino Acid Restriction Theory of Aging and Longevity

key_concepts.concept: Dietary amino acid composition influences aging and longevity
key_concepts.description: Restricting certain amino acids, particularly methionine and branched-chain amino acids (BCAAs), can extend lifespan and improve healthspan in multiple species. The theory posits that specific amino acid levels modulate metabolic and signaling pathways that affect aging processes.

key_concepts.concept: Methionine restriction extends lifespan via metabolic and signaling changes
key_concepts.description: Methionine restriction (MR) reduces growth, alters methionine metabolism, and impacts pathways such as mTOR and oxidative stress. MR leads to increased longevity in rodents and flies, possibly through reduced oxidative damage, altered methylation (epigenetic regulation), and production of beneficial metabolites like hydrogen sulfide.

key_concepts.concept: Branched-chain amino acids (BCAAs) modulate aging through mTOR and metabolic health
key_concepts.description: High BCAA levels activate mTOR signaling, which is linked to accelerated aging and metabolic dysfunction. Restricting BCAAs, especially isoleucine, improves metabolic health and can extend lifespan in mice, though effects may be sex- and context-dependent.

key_concepts.concept: Interaction with growth hormone (GH) and insulin/IGF-1 signaling
key_concepts.description: The longevity benefits of amino acid restriction overlap with those seen in GH-deficient or GH receptor-deficient dwarf mice, indicating shared mechanisms involving reduced IGF-1 and altered methionine metabolism.

key_concepts.concept: Complex multifactorial mechanisms involving oxidative stress, epigenetics, and metabolite signaling
key_concepts.description: Amino acid restriction affects glutathione levels, oxidative stress resistance, epigenetic methylation via SAM, and production of signaling molecules like hydrogen sulfide and taurine, all of which are implicated in aging biology.

key_concepts.concept: Dietary context and environmental factors influence outcomes
key_concepts.description: Effects of amino acid restriction depend on genetic background, sex, reproductive status, and environmental conditions such as pathogen exposure and diet composition, highlighting complexity in translating findings to humans.

theories.evidence: Extensive citations of experimental studies in rodents (rats, mice), Drosophila, and other species showing lifespan extension and health benefits from methionine and BCAA restriction; genetic studies linking GH signaling and methionine metabolism; clinical trials and epidemiological data suggesting translational potential in humans.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets all criteria: generalizable across species and genotypes; proposes causal mechanisms involving metabolic and signaling pathways; addresses aging broadly beyond single organs or diseases; supported by mechanistic studies and evolutionary considerations.

results.title: Gone with the Wnts: beta-catenin, T-cell factor, forkhead box O, and oxidative stress in age-dependent diseases of bone, lipid, and glucose metabolism.

theories.name: Oxidative Stress Antagonism of Wnt/beta-Catenin Signaling Theory

key_concepts.concept: Wnt/beta-catenin signaling promotes bone mass and metabolic homeostasis
key_concepts.description: The canonical Wnt/beta-catenin/TCF-mediated gene transcription pathway stimulates osteoblastogenesis, inhibits adipogenesis, reduces osteoblast and osteocyte apoptosis, and supports glucose and lipid metabolism, thereby maintaining bone strength and metabolic health.

key_concepts.concept: Oxidative stress increases with age and diverts beta-catenin from TCF to FOXO-mediated transcription
key_concepts.description: Age-associated oxidative stress induces FOXO transcription factors that compete with TCF for beta-catenin binding, diverting beta-catenin away from Wnt signaling. This shift reduces Wnt-mediated transcription, leading to decreased osteoblastogenesis, increased adipogenesis, and impaired metabolic regulation.

key_concepts.concept: FOXO transcription factors mediate cellular defense against oxidative damage but contribute to aging pathologies
key_concepts.description: FOXO factors upregulate antioxidant enzymes and DNA repair genes to protect cells from oxidative damage. However, their activation at the expense of Wnt signaling leads to adverse effects such as bone loss, insulin resistance, hyperlipidemia, and atherosclerosis, linking oxidative stress to multiple age-related diseases.

key_concepts.concept: Genetic and experimental evidence links attenuation of Wnt signaling to age-related diseases
key_concepts.description: Mutations in LRP6, a Wnt coreceptor, cause premature osteoporosis, coronary artery disease, and metabolic syndrome features. Experimental models show that oxidative stress increases FOXO activity, decreases Wnt target gene expression, and that antioxidants can mitigate bone loss and metabolic dysfunction.

theories.evidence: Citations of genetic studies linking LRP6 mutations to multiple age-related diseases; mouse models showing age-related bone loss associated with increased oxidative stress and FOXO activation; cell culture experiments demonstrating beta-catenin diversion from TCF to FOXO under oxidative stress; antioxidant interventions reversing bone loss and metabolic defects in animal models.
theories.criteria_reasoning: The theory explains a fundamental, organism-level aging mechanism linking oxidative stress to systemic aging phenotypes via modulation of Wnt/beta-catenin and FOXO transcriptional programs. It proposes a causal mechanism for aging-related bone loss and metabolic diseases, supported by genetic, molecular, and physiological data, thus meeting all core criteria for an aging theory.

results.title: Transcriptional memory of dFOXO activation in youth curtails later-life mortality through chromatin remodeling and Xbp1.

theories.name: Transcriptional Memory Theory of Aging via dFOXO Activation

key_concepts.concept: Transcriptional Memory
key_concepts.description: A transient, homeostatic transcriptional event in early adulthood can produce lasting, developmental-like impacts on subsequent gene expression programs, thereby influencing organismal aging.

key_concepts.concept: dFOXO as Longevity-Promoting Transcription Factor
key_concepts.description: Activation of the evolutionarily conserved transcription factor dFOXO in early adult life induces persistent chromatin remodeling and a long-lasting transcriptional program that improves health and extends lifespan in female Drosophila.

key_concepts.concept: Chromatin Remodeling as Mechanism
key_concepts.description: Chromatin remodelers such as SWI/SNF and ISWI complexes are required for establishing the transcriptional memory and longevity benefits induced by early-life dFOXO activation, indicating that chromatin architecture set in youth programs later-life aging outcomes.

key_concepts.concept: dFOXO-to-Xbp1 Transcriptional Relay
key_concepts.description: The transcriptional program induced by early dFOXO activation includes later-life induction of Xbp1, a transcription factor involved in unfolded protein response and proteostasis, which is sufficient to reduce late-life mortality.

key_concepts.concept: Counteraction of Age-Related Transcriptional Dysregulation
key_concepts.description: The transcriptional changes induced by dFOXO-switch counteract age-related gene expression dysregulation in the fat body, suggesting a mechanism by which early-life transcriptional programming can modulate systemic aging.

theories.evidence: Experimental induction of dFOXO in early adult female Drosophila fat body and gut extended lifespan and improved healthspan; ATAC-Seq and RNA-Seq showed persistent chromatin accessibility and transcriptional changes; RNAi knockdown of chromatin remodelers blocked longevity benefits; induction of Xbp1 was shown to be sufficient to reduce late-life mortality; metabolomics and transcriptomics analyses supported metabolic reprogramming and counteraction of age-related transcriptional changes.
theories.criteria_reasoning: The theory explains how a fundamental biological process (transcriptional memory via dFOXO activation) causally influences aging at the organismal level through chromatin remodeling and transcriptional programming, with broad implications beyond a single tissue or disease, meeting all core requirements of generalizability, causal explanation, and scope.

results.title: What can genetic variation tell us about the evolution of senescence?

theories.name: Mutation Accumulation (MA) Theory of Senescence

key_concepts.concept: Declining selection with age
key_concepts.description: The strength of natural selection decreases with age, allowing deleterious mutations that affect late-life survival or reproduction to accumulate in the population.

key_concepts.concept: Late-acting deleterious mutations
key_concepts.description: New germline mutations arise that have harmful effects primarily at older ages, leading to an increased mutational load at late age.

key_concepts.concept: Increase in genetic variance components with age
key_concepts.description: Under MA, additive genetic variance, dominance variance, homozygote variance, and inbreeding depression are predicted to increase with age due to relaxed purifying selection.

theories.evidence: The paper reviews classical quantitative genetic models and empirical studies (e.g., mutation accumulation lines, artificial selection experiments) that have generally supported MA predictions, such as increased inbreeding depression and dominance variance with age. It also discusses theoretical predictions from Charlesworth & Hughes and others.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets all criteria: it is a generalizable evolutionary theory explaining why aging occurs due to mutation accumulation, provides causal mechanisms, and addresses aging broadly at the organismal level.

theories.name: Antagonistic Pleiotropy (AP) Theory of Senescence

key_concepts.concept: Trade-offs between early and late life fitness
key_concepts.description: Genes may have beneficial effects on fitness early in life but deleterious effects later, leading to senescence as a consequence of selection favoring early-life benefits.

key_concepts.concept: Marginal overdominance and balancing selection
key_concepts.description: Some AP loci may maintain stable polymorphisms via heterozygote advantage (marginal overdominance), contributing to genetic variation for aging traits.

key_concepts.concept: Age-dependent genetic effects and dominance
key_concepts.description: The paper proposes a more general AP model where additive and dominance effects on phenotype can increase with age, potentially causing increases in dominance variance and inbreeding depression with age, similar to MA predictions.

key_concepts.concept: Limitations of classical AP models
key_concepts.description: The traditional Charlesworth & Hughes AP model assumes constant additive and dominance effects across age, which may be too restrictive and not reflective of real genetic architectures.

theories.evidence: The paper presents theoretical analysis and modeling contrasting classical AP assumptions with a more stable model of AP involving age-dependent genetic effects. It cites empirical studies and theoretical arguments (e.g., Curtsinger et al., Keightley & Kacser) to support the plausibility of the alternative model.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets all criteria: it is a general evolutionary theory explaining why aging occurs due to pleiotropic gene effects, provides causal mechanisms, and addresses aging broadly at the organismal level.

results.title: SENESCENCE IN NATURAL POPULATIONS OF MAMMALS: A COMPARATIVE STUDY.

theories.name: Antagonistic Pleiotropy Theory of Senescence

key_concepts.concept: Declining selection pressure with age
key_concepts.description: Natural selection weakens as an individual ages, allowing late-acting deleterious mutations to accumulate, which leads to senescent decline in fecundity and survival.

key_concepts.concept: Pleiotropic genes with early benefits and late costs
key_concepts.description: Genes that have beneficial effects early in life but deleterious effects later can be positively selected, increasing their frequency and causing senescence.

key_concepts.concept: Life history parameters influence selection strength
key_concepts.description: The strength of selection for antagonistic pleiotropic genes depends on demographic factors such as adult mortality and intrinsic rate of increase, with stronger selection in species with high adult mortality and short generation times.

theories.evidence: Comparative analysis of 56 natural mammal populations showing higher rates of senescence in short-lived species with rapid development and early maturity, consistent with predictions of the theory; citations of prior theoretical and empirical work.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets all criteria: explains why aging occurs at organism level with evolutionary causal mechanisms; generalizable across species; addresses broad aging process.

theories.name: Disposable Soma Theory of Senescence

key_concepts.concept: Resource allocation trade-off
key_concepts.description: Organisms optimize resource investment between somatic maintenance/repair and reproduction; diverting resources to reproduction reduces maintenance, leading to accumulation of damage and senescence.

key_concepts.concept: Senescence arises from accumulated somatic disrepair
key_concepts.description: When somatic maintenance falls below a critical threshold due to resource allocation to reproduction, intrinsic mortality increases, causing senescence.

key_concepts.concept: Predictions on reproductive investment
key_concepts.description: Species with higher reproductive output relative to body mass should show greater senescence due to less investment in maintenance.

theories.evidence: Phylogenetic regression showing taxa with higher annual reproductive output tend to have higher rates of senescence; discussion of theoretical predictions and partial empirical support.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria: provides causal evolutionary explanation for aging at organism level; generalizable; addresses broad aging process.

theories.name: Brain Size and Homeostasis Theory of Senescence

key_concepts.concept: Brain as a homeostatic organ
key_concepts.description: Larger brains relative to body size improve homeostatic regulation, potentially delaying or minimizing senescence effects.

key_concepts.concept: Learning capacity reduces mortality risks
key_concepts.description: Species with larger brains may learn behaviors that reduce extrinsic mortality causes such as predation and starvation, effectively lowering senescence impact.

theories.evidence: Comparative data showing significant negative correlation between relative brain size and rate of senescence in longer-lived taxa after controlling for confounders.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria: proposes causal mechanism linking brain size to aging at organism level; generalizable across species; addresses broad aging process.

results.title: Accumulation of nuclear DNA damage or neuron loss: molecular basis for a new approach to understanding selective neuronal vulnerability in neurodegenerative diseases.

theories.name: Nuclear DNA Damage Accumulation and Insufficient DNA Repair Theory of Brain Aging

key_concepts.concept: Accumulation of nuclear DNA damage
key_concepts.description: Aging is primarily caused by the accumulation of nuclear DNA (nDNA) damage, especially single-strand breaks (SSBs), in differentiated cells such as neurons due to oxidative stress and other endogenous and exogenous factors.

key_concepts.concept: Decline in DNA repair capacity
key_concepts.description: During aging, there is a decline in the efficiency of nDNA repair mechanisms, particularly base excision repair (BER) and single-strand break repair (SSBR), leading to insufficient repair of accumulated DNA damage.

key_concepts.concept: Cell-type specificity of damage and repair
key_concepts.description: The accumulation of nDNA damage and decline in repair capacity is not uniform across all neuron types; some neurons accumulate more damage and show impaired repair, while others (e.g., Purkinje cells) show different patterns, indicating selective neuronal vulnerability.

key_concepts.concept: Inverse relationship between DNA damage/repair and neuron loss
key_concepts.description: An inverse correlation exists where neurons with higher nDNA damage and lower repair capacity tend to be preserved in number, whereas neurons with very high damage but maintained repair capacity (e.g., Purkinje cells) undergo age-related loss.

key_concepts.concept: Implications for neurodegenerative diseases
key_concepts.description: Selective neuronal vulnerability in diseases like Alzheimer's disease (AD) may be linked to the accumulation of nDNA damage and impaired repair in specific neuron populations, contributing to pathological features such as neurofibrillary tangles.

theories.evidence: The paper reviews autoradiographic studies quantifying nDNA single-strand breaks and unscheduled DNA synthesis (UDS) as a measure of repair in various neuron types in aging mouse brains. It cites studies showing cell-type-specific accumulation of DNA damage and repair decline, stereological neuron counting showing selective neuron loss, and correlations with neurodegenerative disease pathology.
theories.criteria_reasoning: The theory attempts to explain WHY aging occurs at the organismal brain level by proposing a causal mechanism (accumulation of nDNA damage due to insufficient repair) that is generalizable beyond specific diseases or organs. It addresses fundamental aging processes in neurons and links them to systemic aging and neurodegeneration, thus meeting all core requirements.

results.title: Evolution of human longevity uncoupled from caloric restriction mechanisms.

theories.name: Caloric Restriction (CR) Theory of Aging

key_concepts.concept: Caloric Restriction Extends Lifespan
key_concepts.description: Reducing calorie intake by 10-40% without malnutrition delays morbidity and mortality across multiple species, including yeast, worms, flies, rodents, and primates, by affecting fundamental biological pathways.

key_concepts.concept: CR Alters Key Longevity Pathways
key_concepts.description: CR modulates insulin/IGF signaling and mTOR pathways, which regulate growth, metabolism, and cellular maintenance, thereby influencing aging and lifespan.

key_concepts.concept: CR-Induced Transcriptomic Changes
key_concepts.description: CR causes widespread gene expression changes in multiple tissues, including genes involved in metabolism, immune response, oxidative stress, and damage repair, which collectively contribute to lifespan extension.

key_concepts.concept: CR-Mimicking Agents
key_concepts.description: Pharmaceuticals such as resveratrol and rapamycin partially mimic CR effects by targeting similar pathways (e.g., mTOR inhibition), leading to improved healthspan and lifespan extension in model organisms.

theories.evidence: The paper compares transcriptome data from CR-treated mice and CR-mimetic treated mice (resveratrol, rapamycin) with transcriptomes of humans and other primates. It uses multiple datasets across tissues and developmental stages, statistical correlation analyses, gene clustering, and pathway enrichment to test whether human longevity evolved via CR-like mechanisms.
theories.criteria_reasoning: The CR theory meets all criteria: it is a generalizable biological theory explaining why aging occurs via nutrient-sensing pathways; it proposes causal mechanisms (insulin/IGF, mTOR signaling); it addresses aging broadly across species and tissues; and it is the main focus of the paper.

theories.name: Evolutionary Theory of Human Longevity Independent of CR Mechanisms

key_concepts.concept: Human Longevity Evolved Independently of CR
key_concepts.description: Despite CR extending lifespan in many species, humans do not exhibit a CR-like transcriptomic state compared to other primates, suggesting that human longevity evolved through mechanisms distinct from CR-induced pathways.

key_concepts.concept: Human Transcriptome Resembles Well-Fed State
key_concepts.description: Human gene expression patterns across multiple tissues more closely resemble ad libitum-fed mice rather than CR mice, indicating a physiological state associated with higher caloric intake.

key_concepts.concept: Dietary and Genetic Factors in Human Longevity
key_concepts.description: The shift in human physiology may reflect increased calorie and nutrient intake during evolution, and longevity may be linked to other genetic adaptations unrelated to CR pathways.

key_concepts.concept: Potential for CR or CR-Mimetics to Extend Human Lifespan
key_concepts.description: Since humans are not already in a CR-like state, CR or CR-mimicking interventions may still have potential to extend healthy human lifespan.

theories.evidence: Transcriptomic comparisons between humans and other primates show no CR-like signature in humans. Statistical analyses across tissues and developmental stages consistently support this. The paper also discusses evolutionary and physiological data supporting this conclusion.
theories.criteria_reasoning: This theory proposes a causal explanation for why human longevity differs from other primates and why it is uncoupled from CR mechanisms. It is generalizable at the organism level and addresses fundamental aging processes, thus meeting criteria.

theories.name: mTOR Pathway Suppression as a Longevity Mechanism

key_concepts.concept: mTOR Regulates Aging and Longevity
key_concepts.description: The mammalian target of rapamycin (mTOR) pathway controls cell growth and mortality in response to nutrient availability and is a central mediator of CR effects on lifespan.

key_concepts.concept: Rapamycin Extends Lifespan by mTOR Inhibition
key_concepts.description: Rapamycin, an mTOR inhibitor, extends lifespan in mice even when administered late in life, suggesting mTOR suppression as a viable intervention for aging.

key_concepts.concept: Timing of Intervention in Humans
key_concepts.description: Transcriptomic alignment suggests that the physiological state of 600-day-old mice corresponds roughly to 62-66-year-old humans, indicating a potential window for effective rapamycin-like therapies in middle-aged humans.

theories.evidence: Dynamic time-warping analysis comparing mouse and human brain transcriptomes, focusing on mTOR pathway genes, estimates corresponding physiological ages. The paper cites lifespan extension data from rapamycin-treated mice.
theories.criteria_reasoning: This theory provides a causal mechanism for aging via nutrient signaling pathways and proposes translational implications for human aging interventions. It is generalizable and mechanistic, thus meeting criteria.

results.title: Nutrient control of Drosophila longevity.

theories.name: Nutrient Sensing and Insulin/IGF Signaling (IIS) Theory of Dietary Restriction-Induced Longevity

key_concepts.concept: Dietary Restriction (DR) Extends Lifespan by Modulating Nutrient Ratios
key_concepts.description: DR extends lifespan not by reducing total calories but by altering the ratio of protein to carbohydrates consumed, with longevity maximized at a low protein:carbohydrate ratio (approximately 1:16).

key_concepts.concept: Insulin/IGF Signaling (IIS) as a Mediator of Nutrient Effects on Aging
key_concepts.description: Reduced IIS activity, through decreased secretion of insulin-like peptides (DILPs) or mutations in IIS pathway components, is associated with increased lifespan, suggesting IIS mediates nutrient-dependent longevity effects.

key_concepts.concept: Fat Body as an Endocrine Nutrient Sensor
key_concepts.description: The Drosophila fat body senses dietary protein and carbohydrate levels and produces hormonal signals such as DILP6 and Upd2, which modulate IIS by regulating secretion of DILPs from insulin-producing cells (IPCs) in the brain.

key_concepts.concept: Hypothalamic-like Neuronal Integration of Nutrient Signals
key_concepts.description: Neurons expressing short neuropeptide F (sNPF), analogous to mammalian hypothalamic neuropeptide Y (NPY), integrate fat body signals and regulate DILP expression and secretion, coordinating feeding behavior and aging.

key_concepts.concept: Complex Gene-by-Diet Interactions and Nutritional Geometric Framework (NGF)
key_concepts.description: Longevity responses to diet depend on complex interactions between genotype and nutrient composition, best analyzed using NGF, which models lifespan as a function of protein and carbohydrate intake across a nutritional landscape.

theories.evidence: Experimental data from Drosophila dietary manipulation studies measuring lifespan across varying protein:carbohydrate ratios; gene-by-diet interaction analyses with mutants in IIS pathway components (dfoxo, chico, dilps); hormonal assays of DILP secretion; olfactory sensory neuron mutants affecting lifespan; use of holidic diets; and neuroendocrine signaling studies.
theories.criteria_reasoning: This theory meets all criteria: it provides a generalizable, causal explanation for aging by linking nutrient sensing and endocrine signaling to systemic aging processes; it addresses aging broadly at the organismal level; and it integrates molecular, physiological, and behavioral mechanisms.

theories.name: Target of Rapamycin (TOR) Signaling Pathway as a Nutrient-Sensing Mediator of Aging

key_concepts.concept: TOR as a Cellular and Systemic Nutrient Sensor
key_concepts.description: TOR kinase responds to amino acid availability and regulates translation, autophagy, and other cellular processes that influence aging.

key_concepts.concept: Interaction with Insulin/IGF Signaling
key_concepts.description: TOR activity is modulated by IIS via AKT phosphorylation, linking systemic nutrient sensing to cellular growth and aging pathways.

key_concepts.concept: 4eBP as a Downstream Effector of TOR in Longevity Control
key_concepts.description: 4eBP represses translation and is transcriptionally regulated by dFOXO; mutants lacking 4eBP have been used to test TOR's role in DR-induced longevity.

theories.evidence: Gene-by-diet interaction studies using 4eBP null mutants show conflicting results regarding TOR’s requirement for DR-induced lifespan extension; biochemical and genetic data linking TOR to nutrient sensing and aging.
theories.criteria_reasoning: The TOR pathway is discussed as a candidate causal mechanism for aging, with systemic and cell-autonomous nutrient sensing roles, thus meeting criteria for a generalizable aging theory, though current evidence is ambiguous.

theories.name: Sensory Modulation of Aging via Olfactory Perception of Nutrients

key_concepts.concept: Olfactory Neurons Influence Longevity Independently of Ingestion
key_concepts.description: Perception of yeast odors, particularly CO2 sensed by specific olfactory neurons, can reduce lifespan extension normally induced by dietary restriction.

key_concepts.concept: Role of Odorant-Binding Protein Or83b and CO2 Receptors
key_concepts.description: Mutations in Or83b and CO2 receptor Gr63a extend lifespan and alter metabolism, indicating sensory input modulates systemic aging pathways.

theories.evidence: Mutant studies of olfactory receptors and neurons showing altered lifespan and metabolic phenotypes; experiments where flies exposed to yeast odor without ingestion had blunted DR benefits.
theories.criteria_reasoning: This theory proposes a causal mechanism by which sensory perception modulates systemic aging processes, generalizable beyond specific tissues, thus meeting criteria for an aging theory.

results.title: Retirement as Meaningful: Positive Retirement Stereotypes Associated with Longevity.

theories.name: Stereotype Embodiment Theory (SET)

key_concepts.concept: Internalization of Age Stereotypes
key_concepts.description: Age stereotypes, including those about retirement, are internalized across the lifespan starting from a young age, often unconsciously.

key_concepts.concept: Self-Relevance and Salience
key_concepts.description: These internalized stereotypes gain particular relevance and salience as individuals approach old age or retirement, becoming self-relevant.

key_concepts.concept: Impact on Health via Multiple Pathways
key_concepts.description: The internalized stereotypes influence health outcomes and mortality risk through multiple mediating pathways, including health behaviors, psychological adjustment, and physiological effects.

key_concepts.concept: Extension to Retirement Stereotypes
key_concepts.description: The theory is extended to explain how stereotypes specifically about retirement—both mental and physical health expectations—affect longevity and mortality risk.

theories.evidence: Longitudinal cohort study of 1,011 older adults over 23 years showing that positive retirement stereotypes about mental and physical health are associated with significantly lower mortality risk and increased survival by 2.5 and 4.5 years respectively, controlling for multiple covariates. Supported by prior studies linking positive age stereotypes to better health outcomes.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets all criteria: generalizable to organism-level psychosocial aging processes; proposes causal mechanisms by which internalized stereotypes influence health and mortality; addresses broad psychosocial aging rather than narrow phenomena.

results.title: Animal and human models to understand ageing.

theories.name: Insulin/IGF-1 Signaling (IIS) Pathway Theory of Aging

key_concepts.concept: Conserved nutrient sensing pathway
key_concepts.description: The IIS pathway integrates signals from insulin-like growth factors to regulate growth, metabolism, and stress responses, influencing lifespan across species from yeast to humans.

key_concepts.concept: Genetic modulation of lifespan
key_concepts.description: Mutations in genes such as age-1 in C. elegans and insulin receptor substrate Chico in Drosophila extend lifespan, demonstrating IIS as a causal regulator of aging.

key_concepts.concept: FOXO transcription factors as effectors
key_concepts.description: FOXO proteins (e.g., DAF-16 in worms, FOXO3 in humans) mediate downstream effects of IIS, promoting stress resistance and longevity; human FOXO3 polymorphisms associate with lifespan extension.

theories.evidence: Genetic studies in C. elegans, Drosophila, and human population SNP associations; lifespan extension by IIS pathway mutations; conserved pathway components identified across model organisms.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets all criteria: explains a fundamental, conserved causal mechanism of aging applicable broadly across organisms; proposes underlying biochemical and genetic causes.

theories.name: mTOR Signaling Pathway Theory of Aging

key_concepts.concept: mTOR as a central nutrient and stress sensor
key_concepts.description: The mechanistic target of rapamycin (mTOR) kinase integrates nutrient availability and stress signals to regulate cell growth, metabolism, and autophagy, influencing aging.

key_concepts.concept: Caloric restriction and mTOR inhibition extend lifespan
key_concepts.description: Caloric restriction extends lifespan in yeast, worms, flies, mice, and primates, largely through downregulation of mTOR signaling; pharmacological inhibition by rapamycin also extends lifespan.

key_concepts.concept: Downstream effectors modulate aging processes
key_concepts.description: mTOR modulates targets such as S6 kinase and FOXO transcription factors, affecting protein synthesis, autophagy, and stress resistance, which are key to aging regulation.

theories.evidence: Genetic deletion of TOR1 in yeast increases lifespan; rapamycin treatment extends lifespan in mice and improves healthspan; conserved pathway components identified in multiple species.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets all criteria: provides a generalizable, causal biochemical mechanism underlying aging across species; supported by experimental interventions.

theories.name: Cellular Senescence Theory of Aging

key_concepts.concept: Irreversible cell cycle arrest with viability
key_concepts.description: Senescent cells cease dividing but remain metabolically active, exhibiting morphological and metabolic changes including increased lysosomal mass and altered metabolism.

key_concepts.concept: Senescent cells accumulate with age and cause tissue dysfunction
key_concepts.description: Accumulation of senescent cells disrupts tissue homeostasis and promotes inflammation via the senescence-associated secretory phenotype (SASP), contributing causally to aging and age-related diseases.

key_concepts.concept: Removal of senescent cells delays aging phenotypes
key_concepts.description: Genetic clearance of p16Ink4a-positive senescent cells in mice delays age-related pathologies and extends lifespan; senolytic drugs selectively eliminate senescent cells and rejuvenate tissues.

theories.evidence: Mouse models with INK-ATTAC transgene show delayed aging upon senescent cell clearance; senolytic drugs (ABT263, dasatinib + quercetin) improve healthspan in aged mice; human cell studies of senescence pathways.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets all criteria: proposes a causal cellular mechanism for systemic aging; supported by experimental genetic and pharmacological evidence; broadly applicable across tissues and species.

theories.name: Damage Accumulation Theory (DNA Damage and Telomere Attrition)

key_concepts.concept: Accumulation of DNA damage triggers aging
key_concepts.description: DNA damage accumulates stochastically over time, leading to genomic instability, impaired cellular function, and activation of senescence or apoptosis pathways.

key_concepts.concept: Telomere shortening induces replicative senescence
key_concepts.description: Progressive telomere attrition during cell division triggers DNA damage responses that induce cellular senescence, limiting regenerative capacity and contributing to organismal aging.

key_concepts.concept: Premature aging syndromes illustrate damage-driven aging
key_concepts.description: Human progeroid syndromes (e.g., Werner syndrome, Hutchinson-Gilford progeria) caused by mutations in DNA repair or nuclear envelope genes show accelerated aging phenotypes, linking DNA damage to aging.

theories.evidence: Studies of human premature aging syndromes; mouse models combining WRN mutation with telomerase deficiency recapitulate aging phenotypes; in vitro human cell senescence triggered by telomere shortening.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria: explains a fundamental causal mechanism of aging at cellular and organismal levels; supported by genetic and experimental evidence; broadly relevant across tissues.

theories.name: Evolutionary Theories of Aging (Antagonistic Pleiotropy and Disposable Soma)

key_concepts.concept: Trade-off between reproduction and somatic maintenance
key_concepts.description: Organisms allocate limited resources between reproduction and maintenance; investment in reproduction may reduce resources for repair, leading to aging.

key_concepts.concept: Genes beneficial early in life may have deleterious effects later
key_concepts.description: Antagonistic pleiotropy posits that genes selected for reproductive success can have negative effects in post-reproductive life, contributing to aging.

key_concepts.concept: Species differences in aging reflect evolutionary strategies
key_concepts.description: Differences in lifespan and aging patterns among species (e.g., mice vs. naked mole rats) reflect evolutionary trade-offs and life history strategies.

theories.evidence: Comparative biology of rodents with different lifespans; theoretical framework supported by genetic and ecological observations; referenced evolutionary logic underlying aging.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria: provides a generalizable causal evolutionary explanation for aging; applicable at organismal level; supported by comparative and genetic data.

results.title: Risky family climates presage increased cellular aging in young adulthood.

theories.name: Risky Family Climate - Sympathetic Nervous System Activation Theory of Accelerated Cellular Aging

key_concepts.concept: Risky Family Climate
key_concepts.description: A psychosocial environment during childhood characterized by parental depression, harsh-inconsistent parenting, and low parental warmth, support, and involvement. This environment is hypothesized to calibrate the body's stress response systems in a way that predisposes individuals to health problems later in life.

key_concepts.concept: Sympathetic Nervous System (SNS) Overactivation
key_concepts.description: Exposure to risky family climates leads to persistent and excessive activation of the SNS, resulting in elevated tonic output of catecholamines (epinephrine and norepinephrine). While acute SNS activation is adaptive, chronic overactivation can damage tissues and organs.

key_concepts.concept: Catecholamine-Mediated Cellular Aging
key_concepts.description: Elevated catecholamine levels contribute causally to accelerated cellular aging, as indexed by DNA methylation-based epigenetic clocks. This accelerated aging is a potential intermediate biomarker linking early psychosocial adversity to later-life chronic diseases.

key_concepts.concept: Epigenetic Aging as a Biomarker
key_concepts.description: DNA methylation patterns at specific CpG sites provide a measure of biological age that can diverge from chronological age. Accelerated epigenetic aging predicts increased risk for cardiovascular disease, cancer, obesity, and mortality.

theories.evidence: Longitudinal prospective cohort data from 323 rural Black youth showed that risky family climates at age 11 predicted higher catecholamine levels at ages 19-20, which in turn predicted accelerated cellular aging from ages 20 to 27, measured by DNA methylation epigenetic clocks. Statistical mediation analysis supported an indirect effect of risky family climate on cellular aging via catecholamines. The study controlled for confounders including BMI, smoking, socioeconomic risk, and intervention status.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets all criteria: The theory explains HOW biological aging occurs at the organism level by linking early psychosocial stress to systemic SNS overactivation and consequent cellular aging. It proposes a causal mechanism (SNS catecholamine overproduction) that affects a general aging biomarker (epigenetic aging) applicable to the whole organism. The scope is broad, connecting psychosocial environment to biological aging processes, not limited to specific organs or diseases.

results.title: Radiation symptoms resemble laminopathies and the physical underlying cause may sit at the lamin A C-terminus.

theories.name: Radiation-induced laminopathy theory

key_concepts.concept: Lamin A C-terminal oxidation
key_concepts.description: Ionizing radiation causes oxidative damage specifically at three highly conserved cysteine residues (C522, C588, C591) in the lamin A C-terminus. This oxidation can shift from functional disulfide bonds to damaging sulfonic acid species, impairing lamin A function and leading to nuclear envelope destabilization.

key_concepts.concept: Lamin A damage as a common cause of radiation effects
key_concepts.description: The theory proposes that the diverse radiation responses—cancer growth, tissue ablation, and deterministic senescence—share a mechanistic origin in damage to lamin A, complementing the classical DNA damage model.

key_concepts.concept: Lamin A accumulation impacts nuclear pore complexes and ATM shuttling
key_concepts.description: Oxidized lamin A accumulates at the nuclear envelope, forming pore-free islands that hinder nuclear pore complex formation and slow ATM nucleo-shuttling, thereby affecting DNA damage response kinetics.

key_concepts.concept: Micronuclei instability and cGAS-STING activation
key_concepts.description: Cells with higher lamin A form micronuclei with lamin A-rich envelopes prone to rupture under oxidative stress, releasing DNA that activates the cGAS-STING pathway, promoting inflammation and cellular senescence.

key_concepts.concept: Compensatory role of lamin B1/B2
key_concepts.description: Cells with higher lamin B1/2 can compensate for lamin A damage by enabling oxidative stress responses and maintaining cell cycle progression, but at the cost of increased genomic instability and cancer risk.

key_concepts.concept: Phosphorylation of lamins links to DNA damage kinases
key_concepts.description: ATM and ATR kinases phosphorylate lamin proteins at SQ/TQ motifs, connecting lamin dynamics to DNA damage response and mitotic nuclear envelope disassembly, influencing radiosensitivity.

theories.evidence: The paper integrates structural modeling (AlphaFold predictions), literature on lamin A oxidation and laminopathy, experimental data on cysteine mutants, correlations of lamin expression with radiosensitivity in cell types, and known molecular interactions between lamin A and DNA repair proteins (ATM, 53BP1). It also cites clinical parallels between radiation symptoms and progeria laminopathies.
theories.criteria_reasoning: The theory attempts to explain HOW radiation accelerates aging and causes diverse biological effects via a fundamental mechanism involving lamin A oxidation and nuclear envelope destabilization. It proposes causal molecular mechanisms, connects to organism-level aging phenomena (radiodegeneration), and integrates evolutionary and cellular biology insights. It is not limited to a single organ or disease but addresses systemic radiation-induced aging effects.

results.title: Nicotinamide as Independent Variable for Intelligence, Fertility, and Health: Origin of Human Creative Explosions?

theories.name: Nicotinamide Dose-Dependent Evolutionary Aging and Fertility Theory

key_concepts.concept: Nicotinamide as a key metabolic regulator
key_concepts.description: Nicotinamide, derived primarily from meat consumption, is central to NAD metabolism, which drives energy production and influences immune tolerance, fertility, and brain evolution.

key_concepts.concept: Dietary shifts modulate fertility and longevity
key_concepts.description: A high nicotinamide intake from meat correlates with higher longevity but lower fertility, while a shift down the food chain to plant-based diets with lower nicotinamide increases fertility but reduces physical and mental health, influencing demographic transitions.

key_concepts.concept: Immune tolerance and symbiont relationships
key_concepts.description: Reduced dietary nicotinamide increases reliance on de novo synthesis from tryptophan, conditioning the immune system to tolerate symbionts (e.g., TB) and the fetus, thereby enhancing fertility.

key_concepts.concept: Evolutionary trade-offs and demographic transitions
key_concepts.description: The theory proposes that dietary-driven nicotinamide levels underlie major human evolutionary events, including population bottlenecks, the Neolithic agricultural revolution, and recent epidemiological transitions, through trade-offs between fertility, longevity, disease susceptibility, and cognitive development.

key_concepts.concept: Antagonistic pleiotropy in profertility genes
key_concepts.description: Genetic adaptations favoring fertility early in life may increase risks of degenerative diseases later, consistent with antagonistic pleiotropy, influenced by nicotinamide metabolism.

theories.evidence: The paper integrates anthropological, archaeological, genetic, epidemiological, and biochemical data, including correlations between diet and fertility, population bottlenecks, disease patterns (e.g., pellagra, TB), and genetic signatures of profertility genes exhibiting antagonistic pleiotropy.
theories.criteria_reasoning: The theory meets all criteria: it provides a generalizable, causal explanation for aging and fertility changes at the organismal level, linking metabolism, immune function, and evolutionary history; it addresses broad aging-related phenomena beyond specific organs or diseases.

results.title: Linking Environmental Genotoxins to Neurodegenerative Diseases Through Transcriptional Mutagenesis.

theories.name: Transcriptional Mutagenesis Theory of Neurodegenerative Aging

key_concepts.concept: Transcriptional Mutagenesis (TM)
key_concepts.description: TM is the process by which DNA damage causes RNA polymerase to incorporate incorrect bases during transcription, producing mutant RNA transcripts without requiring DNA replication. This leads to mutant proteins in post-mitotic cells like neurons.

key_concepts.concept: Mutant Proteins with Amyloid- and Prion-like Properties
key_concepts.description: Mutant proteins generated by TM can adopt amyloid or prion-like conformations that seed aggregation by converting wild-type proteins into pathological aggregates, driving neurodegenerative disease progression.

key_concepts.concept: Impact on Protein Quality Control
key_concepts.description: TM-induced mutant proteins such as truncated UBB+1 impair proteasomal degradation, while widespread random transcription errors overload protein quality control systems, collectively promoting toxic protein accumulation.

key_concepts.concept: Environmental Genotoxins Induce TM
key_concepts.description: Environmental toxins that cause DNA damage, especially small lesions like O6-methyl-guanine, increase TM rates. Examples include pesticides (rotenone, paraquat), cigarette smoke, and cycad genotoxins like methylazoxymethanol (MAM).

key_concepts.concept: DNA Repair Deficiency Amplifies TM
key_concepts.description: Deficiencies in DNA repair pathways, particularly MGMT and transcription-coupled repair, increase persistence of DNA lesions that induce TM, potentially explaining sex differences in neurodegenerative disease incidence.

key_concepts.concept: TM as a Unifying Mechanism for Inherited and Sporadic Neurodegeneration
key_concepts.description: Inherited neurodegenerative diseases arise from genetic mutations producing mutant proteins, while sporadic cases may result from TM-generated mutant proteins, providing a unified pathophysiological framework.

theories.mode: propose, review, discuss, test (experimental data on MAM and TM), synthesize
theories.evidence: Review of historical and contemporary literature; detection of transcription errors in human neurons and disease tissues; experimental induction of TM by MAM in neural stem cells; epidemiological correlations with environmental toxins; molecular studies on UBB+1 and mutant proteins; RNA sequencing data showing TM ubiquity.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets all criteria: explains a fundamental aging-related process (protein aggregation in neurodegeneration) at organismal level; proposes causal mechanisms linking DNA damage to aging-related neurodegeneration via TM; scope is broad, addressing general neurodegenerative aging processes rather than single organ or disease narrowly.

results.title: Modeling physiological processes that relate toxicant exposure and bacterial population dynamics.

theories.name: Dynamic Energy Budget (DEB) theory with ROS-mediated aging acceleration

key_concepts.concept: Energy budget framework
key_concepts.description: DEB theory models energy acquisition, storage, and allocation to maintenance, growth, and reproduction at the organismal level, linking molecular and cellular processes to population dynamics.

key_concepts.concept: Aging acceleration via reactive oxygen species (ROS)
key_concepts.description: Excess ROS cause damage-inducing compounds (e.g., DNA damage) that accumulate and increase cellular hazard rate (mortality risk). Aging acceleration is a scaled measure of these damage-inducing compounds, driving increased mortality.

key_concepts.concept: Toxicant effects mediated through ROS
key_concepts.description: Toxicants such as cadmium increase ROS production, thereby accelerating aging and increasing hazard rate. The model assumes toxicants do not directly increase mortality but do so indirectly via ROS-induced damage.

key_concepts.concept: Environmental degradation affecting energy conductance
key_concepts.description: Bacterial metabolism degrades the environment (e.g., oxygen depletion), which reduces energy conductance and slows growth, modeled phenomenologically as an exponential decay of energy conductance.

key_concepts.concept: Acclimation energy and lag time
key_concepts.description: Lag time before exponential growth is modeled as energy required for acclimation to toxicants, reflecting energy diverted from growth to damage repair and efflux mechanisms.

theories.evidence: Model fitting and prediction of Pseudomonas aeruginosa growth under various cadmium exposures; comparison of predicted aging acceleration with measured ROS levels; model reproduces growth curves and toxic effects with a single parameter set; predictive ability tested on higher cadmium concentrations.
theories.criteria_reasoning: The DEB theory with ROS-mediated aging acceleration explains how toxicants cause aging and mortality at a general organismal level by proposing a causal mechanism (ROS-induced damage) that affects energy budgets and hazard rates. It is generalizable beyond bacteria, addresses causal mechanisms of aging, and connects molecular damage to population-level aging processes.

results.title: Forkhead transcription factors and ageing.

theories.name: Forkhead transcription factor (FOXO) regulation of aging via insulin/IGF-1 signaling pathway

key_concepts.concept: FOXO as a lifespan regulator
key_concepts.description: FOXO transcription factors, particularly the daf-16 gene in C. elegans and its orthologues in Drosophila and mammals, regulate lifespan by mediating the effects of insulin/IGF-1 signaling (IIS). Reduced IIS leads to activation (nuclear localization) of FOXO, which promotes gene expression changes that extend lifespan.

key_concepts.concept: Conservation of IIS-FOXO pathway across species
key_concepts.description: The IIS pathway and FOXO's role in lifespan extension are evolutionarily conserved from yeast and nematodes to mammals, indicating a fundamental mechanism of aging regulation.

key_concepts.concept: FOXO regulation by post-translational modifications
key_concepts.description: FOXO activity is regulated by phosphorylation (e.g., by Akt, SGK, AMPK) and acetylation (e.g., by SIRT1), which affect its localization, DNA binding, and transcriptional activity, thereby modulating aging and stress resistance.

key_concepts.concept: FOXO cofactors modulate lifespan effects
key_concepts.description: Cofactors such as SMK-1, HSF-1, PHA-4 (Foxa orthologue), and sirtuins interact with FOXO to regulate specific gene subsets, influencing lifespan extension and stress responses.

key_concepts.concept: FOXO links aging to age-related diseases
key_concepts.description: FOXO factors not only regulate lifespan but also modulate aging-related pathologies including cancer, metabolic diseases (diabetes, obesity), and neurodegeneration, suggesting a mechanistic link between aging and disease.

theories.evidence: Genetic studies in C. elegans (daf-2, daf-16 mutants), Drosophila (dFOXO overexpression), and mice (Irs1 null mutants) show lifespan extension linked to FOXO activity; biochemical studies demonstrate FOXO regulation by phosphorylation and acetylation; genetic screens identify FOXO cofactors; population genetics implicate FOXO variants in human longevity; studies link FOXO to cancer suppression and neurodegeneration models.
theories.criteria_reasoning: The theory explains a fundamental, evolutionarily conserved mechanism of aging regulation at the organismal level via FOXO transcription factors modulated by IIS and cofactors. It proposes causal mechanisms (gene regulation changes mediated by FOXO) for aging and links to aging-related diseases, meeting all core criteria of generalizability, causal explanation, and broad scope.

theories.name: Dietary restriction (DR) lifespan extension mediated by forkhead transcription factors

key_concepts.concept: DR extends lifespan via forkhead factors
key_concepts.description: Dietary restriction increases lifespan in multiple organisms, and in C. elegans, the forkhead transcription factor PHA-4 (Foxa orthologue) is essential for DR-mediated lifespan extension, acting independently of daf-16/FOXO in some contexts.

key_concepts.concept: Multiple pathways for DR effects
key_concepts.description: Different methods of DR may act through distinct pathways; some require daf-16/FOXO, others require PHA-4, indicating complexity and possible evolutionary convergence.

key_concepts.concept: Cofactor involvement in DR response
key_concepts.description: SMK-1 is required for DR lifespan extension in C. elegans and may interact with forkhead factors other than DAF-16, highlighting the importance of cofactors in mediating DR effects.

theories.evidence: Genetic RNAi screens in C. elegans identify PHA-4 as necessary for DR lifespan extension; genetic interaction studies show SMK-1 involvement; mammalian Foxa proteins have metabolic roles suggesting possible conservation.
theories.criteria_reasoning: The theory addresses a broad, fundamental aging intervention (DR) and proposes forkhead transcription factors as causal mediators of lifespan extension, with evidence across species. It explains mechanisms beyond narrow phenomena and links to general aging processes.

theories.name: FOXO regulation of aging-related diseases as a mechanistic link between aging and pathology

key_concepts.concept: FOXO as tumor suppressors
key_concepts.description: FOXO proteins regulate cell cycle arrest, DNA repair, and apoptosis, acting as tumor suppressors; their dysregulation is implicated in cancer development and progression.

key_concepts.concept: FOXO in metabolic disease regulation
key_concepts.description: FOXO factors regulate adipocyte differentiation, pancreatic beta-cell survival, hepatic gluconeogenesis, and central energy homeostasis, linking them to diabetes and obesity.

key_concepts.concept: FOXO in neurodegeneration
key_concepts.description: FOXO/DAF-16 modulates protein aggregation and toxicity in models of Alzheimer's disease, with involvement of cofactors like SIRT1, suggesting a role in neurodegenerative disease progression.

theories.evidence: Genetic and molecular studies show FOXO involvement in tumor suppression, metabolic regulation, and neurodegeneration models; experimental data from C. elegans, mice, and human association studies support these roles.
theories.criteria_reasoning: This theory links FOXO-mediated gene regulation to multiple aging-related diseases, proposing a causal mechanism connecting aging processes to pathology broadly, thus meeting the criteria for a generalizable aging theory.

results.title: The metabolic syndrome, IGF-1, and insulin action.

theories.name: Insulin/IGF-1 Signaling Pathway Theory of Aging and Longevity

key_concepts.concept: Conserved insulin/IGF-1 signaling pathway regulates lifespan
key_concepts.description: Mutations in genes involved in insulin/IGF-1 signaling (e.g., daf-2, age-1 in C. elegans; InR, chico in Drosophila; GH/IGF-1 receptor in mice) extend lifespan in model organisms, suggesting this pathway is a fundamental regulator of aging.

key_concepts.concept: Reduced insulin/IGF-1 signaling promotes longevity
key_concepts.description: Long-lived mutant animals with reduced insulin/IGF-1 signaling show increased stress resistance, decreased reactive oxygen species (ROS) production, and delayed aging, indicating a causal mechanism linking pathway downregulation to lifespan extension.

key_concepts.concept: Human longevity and insulin/IGF-1 signaling is complex and context-dependent
key_concepts.description: Human studies show conflicting results; while some polymorphisms in IGF-1 receptor and insulin receptor genes are enriched in centenarians, low IGF-1 levels in older adults are associated with frailty and higher mortality, suggesting that optimal rather than simply low signaling may be beneficial.

key_concepts.concept: Preserved insulin sensitivity as a hallmark of healthy aging
key_concepts.description: Centenarians maintain higher insulin sensitivity compared to younger elderly individuals, which correlates with lower prevalence of metabolic syndrome and better survival, indicating that efficient insulin action is a key physiological feature influencing longevity.

theories.evidence: Extensive citations of genetic and lifespan studies in C. elegans, Drosophila, and mice; human genetic association studies in centenarians; epidemiological data on insulin sensitivity and metabolic syndrome prevalence in centenarians; longitudinal cohort studies linking insulin-related hormones to survival.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets all criteria: generalizable across species including humans, proposes causal mechanisms (insulin/IGF-1 signaling modulates aging processes), addresses aging broadly (systemic metabolic regulation and longevity), and is the main focus of the paper.

theories.name: Adipose Tissue Metabolism and Adipokine Regulation Theory of Aging

key_concepts.concept: Adipose tissue as an endocrine organ influencing aging
key_concepts.description: Adipose tissue secretes adipokines (e.g., adiponectin, leptin) that regulate insulin sensitivity, inflammation, and lipid metabolism, thereby impacting systemic metabolic health and aging.

key_concepts.concept: Adiponectin as an insulin-sensitizing and longevity-associated hormone
key_concepts.description: Higher adiponectin levels correlate with improved insulin sensitivity, reduced oxidative stress, and extended lifespan in animal models; centenarians exhibit elevated adiponectin levels associated with favorable metabolic profiles.

key_concepts.concept: Visceral fat accumulation and dysregulated adipokines contribute to metabolic syndrome and aging
key_concepts.description: Age-related visceral fat increase and adipokine imbalance promote insulin resistance and metabolic syndrome, which are linked to morbidity and mortality in aging populations.

key_concepts.concept: Integrated metabolic network involving CNS, adipokines, and peripheral tissues
key_concepts.description: A complex system including hypothalamic regulation, adipose-derived signals, and sympathetic nervous system coordinates energy homeostasis; dysfunction leads to insulin resistance and aging-related metabolic decline.

theories.evidence: Animal model studies (FIRKO mice, adiponectin transgenic mice), human epidemiological data on adiponectin and metabolic syndrome in centenarians, longitudinal biomarker studies linking adipose endocrine function to survival.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a systemic causal mechanism linking adipose tissue metabolism and adipokine signaling to aging and longevity, with broad organism-level implications.

results.title: Attenuation of primate aging via systemic infusion of senescence-resistant mesenchymal progenitor cells.

theories.name: FOXO3-enhanced mesenchymal progenitor cell rejuvenation theory

key_concepts.concept: Stem cell exhaustion and cellular senescence as drivers of aging
key_concepts.description: Aging is driven by progressive functional decline caused by stem cell exhaustion, chronic inflammation, and accumulation of senescent cells, which impair tissue repair and regeneration.

key_concepts.concept: FOXO3 transcription factor as a key regulator of cellular resilience and longevity
key_concepts.description: FOXO3 activity declines with age, and enhancing FOXO3 function in mesenchymal progenitor cells (MPCs) improves their resistance to oxidative and genotoxic stress, reduces senescence markers, and maintains genomic stability, thereby rejuvenating tissue repair capacity.

key_concepts.concept: Systemic administration of FOXO3-enhanced MPCs (SRCs) slows multi-organ aging
key_concepts.description: Intravenous infusion of FOXO3-engineered, senescence-resistant MPCs in aged primates leads to improved cognitive function, preserved brain structure, bone integrity, immune rejuvenation, and reduced biological age across multiple organs.

key_concepts.concept: Exosome-mediated paracrine signaling as a mechanism of systemic rejuvenation
key_concepts.description: SRC-derived exosomes enriched with gero-protective proteins and metabolites mediate anti-aging effects by reducing senescent cell burden and reversing age-related gene expression changes in multiple tissues.

theories.evidence: Experimental data from a 44-week preclinical trial in aged cynomolgus macaques showing improved physiological, cognitive, imaging, and molecular aging markers after SRC infusion; transcriptomic and DNA methylation aging clocks demonstrating biological age reduction; in vitro and in vivo assays confirming exosome-mediated rejuvenation; prior literature linking FOXO3 to longevity and cellular resilience.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets all criteria: the theory explains HOW aging occurs at organismal level via stem cell exhaustion and senescence; proposes a causal mechanism involving FOXO3 activity decline and its restoration; addresses systemic aging across multiple organs; supported by mechanistic and experimental evidence.

results.title: Calorie restriction hysteretically primes aging Saccharomyces cerevisiae toward more effective oxidative metabolism.

theories.name: Calorie Restriction-Induced Enhancement of Oxidative Metabolism as a Mechanism for Lifespan Extension in Saccharomyces cerevisiae

key_concepts.concept: Calorie Restriction (CR) Extends Lifespan
key_concepts.description: Reducing glucose availability in the culture media (CR) prolongs the chronological lifespan of S. cerevisiae, consistent with observations in other organisms.

key_concepts.concept: CR Promotes a Metabolic Shift from Fermentation to Oxidative Metabolism
key_concepts.description: CR leads to increased respiratory rates by shifting metabolism from fermentative glucose metabolism (to ethanol) toward oxidative metabolism, especially after glucose exhaustion.

key_concepts.concept: Hysteretic Effect of Glucose Limitation on Respiratory Metabolism
key_concepts.description: The increase in oxygen consumption and respiratory metabolism occurs many hours after glucose is depleted, indicating a hysteresis where past glucose limitation primes cells for enhanced oxidative metabolism.

key_concepts.concept: Respiratory Competence is Required for CR-Mediated Lifespan Extension
key_concepts.description: Respiratory-incompetent (ρ0) yeast cells lacking mitochondrial DNA do not show lifespan extension under CR, indicating that enhanced respiration is causally necessary for CR benefits.

key_concepts.concept: Increased Efficiency of Respiratory Substrate Utilization
key_concepts.description: CR cells show earlier, faster, and more efficient metabolism of respiratory substrates such as ethanol and glycerol, contributing to improved biomass formation and energy conversion.

key_concepts.concept: pH Changes Are Not Solely Responsible for Lifespan Extension
key_concepts.description: Although CR alters extracellular pH via metabolic changes, buffering pH does not abolish lifespan extension, indicating that pH changes are not the primary causal mechanism.

theories.evidence: Experimental measurements of oxygen consumption, substrate and metabolite concentrations, biomass formation, growth rates, and chronological lifespan in wild-type and respiratory-incompetent yeast under control and CR conditions; time-course metabolic profiling; lifespan assays with pH buffering; comparison of respiratory competent and incompetent strains.
theories.criteria_reasoning: The theory attempts to explain WHY and HOW aging (chronological lifespan) is extended by CR at the organismal level in yeast, proposing a causal mechanism involving metabolic reprogramming toward enhanced oxidative metabolism. It generalizes beyond a narrow phenomenon by linking metabolic state to lifespan, proposes a causal mechanism (respiratory metabolism enhancement), and addresses aging broadly rather than a single organ or disease. Thus, it meets all core requirements for an aging theory.

results.title: Condition-dependent mortality exacerbates male (but not female) reproductive senescence and the potential for sexual conflict.

theories.name: Condition-dependent mortality and sex-specific reproductive senescence theory

key_concepts.concept: Condition-dependent extrinsic mortality
key_concepts.description: Mortality that depends on the physiological condition of individuals, such that low-condition individuals are more likely to die due to extrinsic factors like predation. This non-random mortality affects the composition of surviving cohorts.

key_concepts.concept: Selective disappearance and survival-reproduction trade-offs
key_concepts.description: Selective disappearance of low-condition individuals leads to cohorts with higher average condition, potentially increasing lifespan but also affecting reproductive senescence due to trade-offs between survival and reproductive maintenance.

key_concepts.concept: Sex-specific effects on reproductive senescence
key_concepts.description: Condition-dependent mortality exacerbates reproductive senescence in males but not females, primarily by accelerating the decline in male post-copulatory fitness components such as offspring viability, while female reproductive senescence remains unaffected.

key_concepts.concept: Male reproductive senescence as a source of sexual conflict
key_concepts.description: Accelerated male reproductive aging under condition-dependent mortality increases costs to females mating with older males, potentially intensifying sexual conflict over mating and reproduction.

key_concepts.concept: Life-history trade-offs shaped by sexual selection and condition-dependent mortality
key_concepts.description: Stronger sexual selection on males and higher condition-dependent extrinsic mortality lead to males adopting 'live fast die young' strategies, prioritizing early reproduction at the expense of somatic and reproductive maintenance, resulting in steeper survival-reproduction trade-offs in males.

theories.evidence: Experimental data from Drosophila melanogaster cohorts exposed to simulated condition-dependent predation showed increased male reproductive senescence (decline in offspring viability) under predation but no effect on female reproductive senescence. Statistical analyses confirmed significant age and mortality treatment effects on reproductive success, fecundity, egg-to-adult viability, mating success, and mating duration. The study also integrates prior literature on life-history evolution, sexual selection, and condition-dependent mortality.
theories.criteria_reasoning: The theory attempts to explain HOW biological aging (reproductive senescence) occurs at the organismal level by proposing mechanisms involving condition-dependent mortality and sex-specific life-history trade-offs. It generalizes beyond a single organ or disease, provides causal explanations for aging patterns, and connects evolutionary and physiological mechanisms. Thus, it meets all core requirements for an aging theory.

results.title: Slower senescence in a wild insect population in years with a more female-biased sex ratio.

theories.name: Life-history trade-off theory of senescence

key_concepts.concept: Resource allocation trade-off
key_concepts.description: Organisms allocate limited resources between somatic maintenance (body upkeep) and reproduction. Investment in reproduction comes at the cost of reduced investment in maintenance, leading to physiological decline and increased mortality with age (senescence).

key_concepts.concept: Antagonistic pleiotropy
key_concepts.description: Alleles that increase reproductive success early in life may have deleterious effects on survival later in life, resulting in a trade-off that shapes aging patterns through evolutionary selection.

key_concepts.concept: Environmental and demographic modulation
key_concepts.description: Environmental factors and demographic variables, such as sex ratio, influence the costs of reproduction and thus modulate the rate of senescence. For example, increased male-male competition raises reproductive investment and accelerates aging.

theories.evidence: Nine years of demographic and behavioral data from a wild population of Gryllus campestris were analyzed. Variation in adult sex ratio was correlated with changes in actuarial senescence (mortality rate increase with age) and phenotypic senescence (decline in male calling activity). Years with more female-biased sex ratios showed slower senescence in both sexes, consistent with predictions of the theory. Statistical modeling using Gompertz mortality models and mixed effects models supported these findings.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets all criteria: The theory explains why aging occurs at an organismal level via resource allocation trade-offs; it is generalizable beyond the specific cricket population; it proposes causal mechanisms linking reproduction costs to senescence; and it addresses aging broadly rather than a narrow disease or organ-specific phenomenon.

results.title: Experimentally increased brood size accelerates actuarial senescence and increases subsequent reproductive effort in a wild bird population.

theories.name: Reproductive Restraint Hypothesis

key_concepts.concept: Trade-off between reproductive effort and somatic maintenance
key_concepts.description: The theory posits that organisms balance current reproductive effort against somatic maintenance to maximize overall fitness, as increased reproductive effort can reduce somatic state and accelerate aging.

key_concepts.concept: Negative covariance between reproductive effort and remaining life expectancy
key_concepts.description: Reproductive effort is restrained early in life when remaining life expectancy is high, and increases as life expectancy decreases, potentially culminating in a terminal reproductive effort when no future reproduction is expected.

key_concepts.concept: Somatic state as a causal mediator
key_concepts.description: Somatic state reduction caused by reproductive effort leads to increased actuarial senescence, which in turn influences reproductive effort, creating a feedback loop between survival prospects and reproductive investment.

theories.evidence: Lifelong brood size manipulation in wild jackdaws showed that increased brood size accelerated actuarial senescence (increased age-dependent mortality rate) and reduced residual lifespan. Birds with reduced somatic state due to increased reproductive effort exhibited increased reproductive effort in subsequent years, evidenced by larger egg volume and higher nestling survival. Statistical survival analyses and reproductive success models supported these findings.
theories.criteria_reasoning: The hypothesis explains WHY and HOW aging occurs through a life-history trade-off mechanism affecting organism-level aging processes. It proposes a causal mechanism linking reproductive effort, somatic state decline, and accelerated aging, with broad applicability to iteroparous organisms. The study experimentally manipulates somatic state and measures organism-level aging and reproduction, fulfilling generalizability, causal explanation, and scope criteria.

results.title: Enhancing Autophagy Diminishes Aberrant Ca<sup>2+</sup> Homeostasis and Arrhythmogenesis in Aging Rabbit Hearts.

theories.name: Autophagy Decline Theory of Cardiac Aging and Arrhythmogenesis

key_concepts.concept: Age-related decrease in autophagy
