key_concepts.description: Autophagy, the cellular process responsible for degrading damaged organelles and proteins, declines with age in the heart, leading to impaired clearance of dysfunctional mitochondria.

key_concepts.concept: Mitochondrial dysfunction and increased mito-ROS
key_concepts.description: Reduced autophagy causes accumulation of damaged mitochondria that produce excessive mitochondria-derived reactive oxygen species (mito-ROS), which contribute to oxidative stress in cardiomyocytes.

key_concepts.concept: Oxidation of ryanodine receptor 2 (RyR2)
key_concepts.description: Excess mito-ROS oxidizes reactive cysteines on RyR2 channels in the sarcoplasmic reticulum, causing hyperactivity and aberrant spontaneous Ca2+ release events that promote arrhythmogenesis.

key_concepts.concept: Restoration of autophagy reduces mito-ROS and arrhythmia risk
key_concepts.description: Enhancing autophagy pharmacologically (Torin1) or genetically (ATG7 overexpression) restores mitochondrial membrane potential, reduces mito-ROS, stabilizes RyR2 function, and decreases pro-arrhythmic spontaneous Ca2+ waves.

theories.evidence: Experimental data from aged rabbit hearts and cultured cardiomyocytes show decreased autophagy markers (p62 accumulation, LC3-II/I ratio changes, reduced PINK1), increased mitochondrial heterogeneity and fission protein DRP1, elevated mito-ROS, RyR2 oxidation, and increased spontaneous Ca2+ waves. Pharmacological inhibition of autophagy with chloroquine increases mito-ROS and arrhythmogenic Ca2+ release, while autophagy enhancement via Torin1 or ATG7 overexpression reverses these effects. Use of mito-ROS scavenger mito-TEMPO rescues Ca2+ handling defects, supporting causal role of mito-ROS downstream of autophagy decline.
theories.criteria_reasoning: The theory explains HOW biological aging at the organismal level (here, cardiac aging) occurs via a fundamental cellular process (autophagy decline) that leads to mitochondrial dysfunction and oxidative damage, causing systemic functional decline (arrhythmogenesis). It proposes causal mechanisms linking autophagy impairment to aging phenotypes, supported by experimental manipulation and measurements. Although focused on cardiac aging, it connects mitochondrial and autophagic dysfunction as general aging mechanisms with systemic consequences, meeting generalizability, causal explanation, and scope criteria.

results.title: Mechanisms of life span extension by rapamycin in the fruit fly Drosophila melanogaster.

theories.name: TOR (Target of Rapamycin) Nutrient-Sensing Pathway Theory of Aging

key_concepts.concept: TOR pathway as a nutrient-sensing regulator of aging
key_concepts.description: The TOR pathway senses nutrient availability and regulates growth, metabolism, and cellular processes accordingly. Downregulation of TOR signaling extends lifespan across diverse organisms, suggesting TOR activity causally influences aging.

key_concepts.concept: TORC1 complex mediates aging via autophagy and translation control
key_concepts.description: TOR kinase functions in two complexes, TORC1 and TORC2. TORC1 regulates protein translation and autophagy. Inhibition of TORC1 by rapamycin induces autophagy and reduces cap-dependent translation, processes that contribute to lifespan extension.

key_concepts.concept: Rapamycin as a pharmacological inhibitor of TORC1 extends lifespan
key_concepts.description: Rapamycin specifically inhibits TORC1 activity by binding FKBP12 and the FRB domain of TOR, reducing phosphorylation of downstream targets S6K and 4E-BP, thereby modulating translation and autophagy to promote longevity.

key_concepts.concept: Interaction and partial independence from insulin/IGF signaling (IIS)
key_concepts.description: While TOR and IIS pathways interact, rapamycin-mediated lifespan extension occurs independently of IIS and AMPK activity changes. Weak IIS downregulation can further extend lifespan beyond rapamycin effects, indicating overlapping but distinct mechanisms.

key_concepts.concept: Autophagy and translation regulation as causal mediators of aging
key_concepts.description: Upregulation of autophagy and downregulation of cap-dependent translation downstream of TORC1 inhibition are necessary for rapamycin-induced lifespan extension, as genetic disruption of these processes abolishes the effect.

key_concepts.concept: Dietary restriction (DR) and TOR pathway share overlapping but distinct mechanisms
key_concepts.description: Rapamycin extends lifespan beyond the maximum achieved by DR, suggesting that TOR inhibition captures some but not all mechanisms of DR-induced longevity.

theories.evidence: Experimental data from Drosophila showing rapamycin feeding extends lifespan, reduces S6K phosphorylation, increases autophagy markers, decreases translation, and increases stress resistance. Genetic epistasis experiments manipulating S6K, 4E-BP, and Atg5 demonstrate necessity of these downstream effectors. Lifespan effects tested in IIS mutants and under dietary restriction conditions.
theories.criteria_reasoning: The TOR nutrient-sensing pathway theory meets all criteria: it provides a generalizable, causal explanation for aging as a fundamental biological process, supported by mechanistic insights and evolutionary conservation. It addresses systemic aging rather than organ-specific or disease-limited phenomena.

results.title: Drosophila Sirtuin 6 mediates developmental diet-dependent programming of adult physiology and survival.

theories.name: Sirt6-mediated developmental nutrient-dependent programming theory of aging

key_concepts.concept: Sirt6 as a metabolic sensor coupling developmental nutrition to adult physiology
key_concepts.description: Sirt6, a NAD+-dependent deacylase, senses nutrient availability during larval development and regulates developmental kinetics and growth, thereby programming adult physiological fitness and lifespan. Its absence leads to accelerated larval development, altered hormone signaling, and adult hypertrophy.

key_concepts.concept: Integration of steroid hormone (ecdysone) and insulin signaling pathways by Sirt6
key_concepts.description: Sirt6 modulates key developmental endocrine pathways, including ecdysone and insulin signaling, which coordinate larval growth and maturation. Loss of Sirt6 leads to upregulation of ecdysone target genes and insulin-like peptides, accelerating development and impacting adult health.

key_concepts.concept: Nutrient-dependent plasticity and physiological memory mediated by Sirt6
key_concepts.description: Sirt6 governs the organism’s ability to respond to varying macronutrient inputs (glucose and yeast/protein) during development, influencing adult stress resistance, metabolic homeostasis, and lifespan. It acts as a molecular link that programs life-history traits based on early nutritional environment.

key_concepts.concept: Evolutionary conservation of Sirt6’s role in aging
key_concepts.description: The study demonstrates that Sirt6’s function in regulating lifespan, metabolic homeostasis, and stress resistance is conserved from mammals to invertebrates, highlighting its fundamental role in organismal aging.

theories.evidence: CRISPR-generated Sirt6 loss-of-function mutants in Drosophila show accelerated larval development, altered ecdysone and insulin signaling gene expression, adult hypertrophy, reduced lifespan, metabolic dysregulation, and impaired stress resistance. Genetic rescue and overexpression experiments restore or improve these phenotypes. Nutritional manipulations during larval stages reveal Sirt6-dependent modulation of developmental timing and adult fitness outcomes.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets all criteria: It proposes a generalizable, causal mechanism explaining how developmental nutrition programs organismal aging and physiology via Sirt6; it addresses systemic aging processes beyond single organs or diseases; it provides mechanistic insights linking nutrient sensing, hormonal signaling, and epigenetic regulation to aging; and it is supported by experimental data in a model organism with evolutionary relevance.

results.title: Positive and negative effects of cellular senescence during female reproductive aging and pregnancy.

theories.name: Cellular Senescence Theory of Aging

key_concepts.concept: Cellular senescence as a cause of aging
key_concepts.description: Cells enter an irreversible growth arrest state called cellular senescence due to stressors like telomere shortening, DNA damage, and oncogenic activation. Accumulation of these senescent cells in tissues reduces regenerative capacity, contributing to organismal and tissue aging.

key_concepts.concept: Senescence-associated secretory phenotype (SASP)
key_concepts.description: Senescent cells secrete proinflammatory cytokines, growth factors, and matrix metalloproteinases collectively termed SASP, which can disrupt tissue homeostasis and promote age-related degenerative diseases.

key_concepts.concept: Dual role of senescent cells in reproduction
key_concepts.description: Senescent cells have antagonistic pleiotropic effects: they accelerate female reproductive aging by depleting ovarian follicles and impairing uterine function, but also play beneficial roles in pregnancy by supporting placental and fetal development.

key_concepts.concept: Antagonistic pleiotropy in cellular senescence
key_concepts.description: Genes controlling cellular senescence may have been evolutionarily selected because their early-life benefits (e.g., fetal development, pregnancy maintenance) outweigh late-life detrimental effects (e.g., reproductive aging), consistent with the antagonistic pleiotropy theory of aging.

theories.evidence: Citations of multiple studies showing increased senescent cells with age in various tissues; experimental evidence from mouse models where elimination of senescent cells delays aging phenotypes; observations of senescent cells in ovarian follicles, uterus, placenta, and fetal tissues; associations of telomere shortening with reproductive decline; molecular markers of senescence (p16, p21, SA-β-gal); studies linking senescence to pregnancy complications and fetal development.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets all criteria: generalizable as it explains aging as a fundamental biological process; provides causal mechanisms (cell cycle arrest, SASP secretion) for aging; addresses aging broadly including systemic reproductive aging and pregnancy; not limited to narrow phenomena.

theories.name: Antagonistic Pleiotropy Theory of Aging (applied to cellular senescence)

key_concepts.concept: Fitness trade-off of genes
key_concepts.description: Certain genes have beneficial effects early in life that enhance reproductive success but have detrimental effects later in life, contributing to aging.

key_concepts.concept: Cellular senescence as an example
key_concepts.description: Cellular senescence genes promote proper fetal development and pregnancy maintenance early in life but cause reproductive aging and tissue dysfunction later, illustrating antagonistic pleiotropy.

theories.evidence: Discussion of senescent cells’ beneficial roles in placental and fetal development contrasted with their negative impact on ovarian and uterine aging; references to George Williams’ original theory; mouse model data showing senescence involvement in development and aging.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it provides an evolutionary causal explanation for aging mechanisms at organismal level and is generalizable beyond specific tissues.

results.title: Evolution of ageing, costs of reproduction and the fecundity-longevity trade-off in eusocial insects.

theories.name: Evolutionary theory of ageing and fecundity-longevity trade-off in eusocial insects

key_concepts.concept: Evolutionary theory of ageing
key_concepts.description: A fundamental evolutionary framework explaining ageing as a consequence of declining natural selection pressure on older individuals due to extrinsic mortality, leading to progressive decline in performance, survivorship, and fecundity with age.

key_concepts.concept: Fecundity-longevity trade-off
key_concepts.description: The general biological principle that investment in reproduction reduces resources available for somatic maintenance, causing a negative association between fecundity and longevity in most organisms.

key_concepts.concept: Reversal of fecundity-longevity trade-off in eusocial queens
key_concepts.description: In eusocial insects, queens often exhibit both high fecundity and exceptional longevity, apparently evading the typical trade-off, possibly due to social protection and remodelling of conserved genetic and endocrine networks.

key_concepts.concept: Condition-dependent longevity and intrinsic quality
key_concepts.description: The idea that only intrinsically high-quality individuals (workers or queens) can overcome the costs of reproduction, leading to positive associations between reproduction and longevity in whole colonies, while reproduction itself still incurs costs.

key_concepts.concept: Genetic and endocrine network mediating trade-off
key_concepts.description: A conserved network involving insulin-like/IGF-1 signalling, juvenile hormone, and vitellogenin mediates the fecundity-longevity trade-off, with potential remodelling in eusocial insects to allow altered relationships.

theories.evidence: Two experiments with eusocial bumblebee Bombus terrestris workers: (1) observational study in whole colonies showing positive association between ovarian activation and longevity; (2) experimental induction of reproduction in randomly selected workers showing negative association, indicating costs of reproduction. Additional behavioral and physiological data support intrinsic quality hypothesis.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets all criteria: generalizable evolutionary theory explaining why and how ageing occurs at organism level; proposes causal mechanisms linking reproduction, intrinsic quality, and ageing; addresses broad ageing patterns in eusocial insects, not limited to specific organs or diseases.

results.title: Impaired redox signaling and antioxidant gene expression in endothelial cells in diabetes: a role for mitochondria and the nuclear factor-E2-related factor 2-Kelch-like ECH-associated protein 1 defense pathway.

theories.name: Nrf2-Keap1 Antioxidant Defense Pathway Theory of Aging and Vascular Dysfunction

key_concepts.concept: Nrf2 as master regulator of cellular redox homeostasis
key_concepts.description: Nrf2 is a redox-sensitive transcription factor that regulates antioxidant response element (ARE)-mediated expression of detoxifying and antioxidant enzymes, maintaining cellular redox balance and protecting cells from oxidative stress.

key_concepts.concept: Dysfunction of Nrf2 signaling contributes to aging and age-related diseases
key_concepts.description: With aging and in type 2 diabetes, Nrf2 expression and activity decline, leading to impaired antioxidant defenses, increased oxidative stress, mitochondrial dysfunction, endothelial dysfunction, and vascular pathologies.

key_concepts.concept: Mitochondrial ROS as both damaging agents and signaling molecules
key_concepts.description: Mitochondrial reactive oxygen species (ROS) overproduction causes oxidative damage but also activates Nrf2 signaling, linking mitochondrial dysfunction to redox regulation and aging.

key_concepts.concept: Nrf2 regulation by Keap1 and multiple kinases
key_concepts.description: Keap1 inhibits Nrf2 under basal conditions; oxidative or electrophilic stress modifies Keap1 cysteines, releasing Nrf2 to translocate to the nucleus. Kinases such as PKC, PI3K/Akt, MAPKs, and GSK-3β modulate Nrf2 activation and nuclear localization.

key_concepts.concept: Nrf2’s role in insulin sensitivity and metabolic regulation
key_concepts.description: Nrf2 activation supports insulin signaling and protects against insulin resistance, while its impairment exacerbates metabolic dysfunction in diabetes.

key_concepts.concept: Nrf2 activation delays cellular senescence and promotes longevity
key_concepts.description: Sustained Nrf2 activation prolongs fibroblast lifespan and resistance to oxidative stress, and animal models with enhanced Nrf2 activity show increased longevity and protection against age-related diseases.

theories.evidence: The paper reviews extensive experimental data from knockout mice, cell culture studies, clinical observations, and molecular signaling analyses demonstrating Nrf2’s role in antioxidant defense, mitochondrial function, insulin sensitivity, vascular protection, and aging. It cites studies showing diminished Nrf2 activity with age, worsened diabetic complications in Nrf2-deficient models, and protective effects of Nrf2 activators.
theories.criteria_reasoning: The theory explains a fundamental biological aging process—oxidative stress and redox imbalance—at the organismal level, proposing a causal mechanism (Nrf2 pathway dysfunction) for aging-related vascular and metabolic decline. It is generalizable beyond diabetes to aging and multiple age-related diseases, meeting all core criteria.

results.title: Microguards and micromessengers of the genome.

theories.name: Microguarding theory of gene expression regulation

key_concepts.concept: Microguarding as buffering gene expression fluctuations
key_concepts.description: Microguarding is the proposed role of microRNAs (miRNAs) in protecting the genome against short-term fluctuations in gene expression, thereby maintaining organismal function and preventing deleterious effects such as genome instability, accelerated aging, and disease.

key_concepts.concept: Microguarding in developmental stability
key_concepts.description: During development, miRNAs fine-tune gene expression oscillations to ensure stable temporal gradients of key transcription factors, preventing developmental arrest caused by transcriptional fluctuations.

key_concepts.concept: Microguarding against reproductive and environmental perturbations
key_concepts.description: miRNAs buffer against gene expression changes induced by mating and infection, reducing fitness costs such as reduced lifespan or reproductive success, by dampening deleterious transcriptional responses.

key_concepts.concept: Microguarding as a mechanism to resolve conflicts of interest
key_concepts.description: Microguarding may have evolved to dampen gene expression oscillations arising from conflicts between genetically distinct cells or individuals (e.g., sexual conflict, cancer cells vs. host cells), thus maintaining homeostasis and fitness.

theories.evidence: Cited experimental studies in Caenorhabditis elegans and Drosophila melanogaster showing miRNA-mediated buffering of developmental and mating-induced gene expression fluctuations; human cell studies linking miRNA expression to inflammation and genome stability; fitness effects observed in miRNA-deficient flies; literature citations supporting miRNA roles in gene regulation and buffering.
theories.criteria_reasoning: The theory proposes a general causal mechanism (miRNA-mediated buffering) explaining how gene expression stability is maintained to prevent accelerated aging and fitness loss, applicable across organisms and contexts, thus meeting generalizability, causal explanation, and broad scope criteria.

theories.name: Micromessenger theory of intercellular and interindividual miRNA communication

key_concepts.concept: miRNAs as extracellular messengers
key_concepts.description: miRNAs can be packaged into microvesicles (MVs) such as exosomes and ectosomes, which protect them from degradation and enable their transport between cells, individuals, and even species.

key_concepts.concept: Specific packaging and targeted delivery
key_concepts.description: Cells selectively package characteristic sets of miRNAs into MVs, which can be delivered to target cells via fusion or endocytosis, potentially altering gene expression in recipient cells.

key_concepts.concept: Micromessengers as agents of biological conflict
key_concepts.description: miRNAs transferred via MVs may mediate conflicts of interest between genetically distinct parties (e.g., males and females, hosts and parasites, cancer cells and normal cells) by manipulating gene expression in target cells.

key_concepts.concept: Potential roles in aging and epigenetic inheritance
key_concepts.description: miRNA-containing MVs may contribute to mechanistic aging and epigenetic inheritance by transferring regulatory RNAs between germ line and soma or between individuals.

theories.evidence: Studies demonstrating miRNA presence in MVs in various biofluids; in vitro experiments showing transfer of miRNAs between immune cells, cancer cells, and across species; observations of MV-mediated modulation of gene expression; examples from Drosophila reproductive biology; hypotheses linking MV miRNAs to aging.
theories.criteria_reasoning: The theory proposes a general mechanism of intercellular and interindividual communication via miRNAs that can causally influence gene expression and organismal function, with implications for aging and evolutionary conflicts, thus meeting the criteria for an aging theory.

theories.name: Conflict hypothesis for microguards and micromessengers

key_concepts.concept: Evolutionary conflicts drive gene expression perturbations
key_concepts.description: Conflicts of interest between genetically distinct entities (e.g., cancer cells vs. host, males vs. females, hosts vs. parasites) cause perturbations in gene expression that can be deleterious.

key_concepts.concept: Microguards evolve to dampen conflict-induced gene expression fluctuations
key_concepts.description: Microguarding mechanisms, primarily via miRNAs, have evolved to buffer and minimize maladaptive gene expression variation arising from these conflicts, thereby protecting organismal fitness.

key_concepts.concept: Micromessengers as mediators and instigators of conflict
key_concepts.description: miRNAs trafficked as micromessengers can act as agents of conflict by manipulating gene expression in other cells or organisms to favor the sender's fitness interests, potentially exacerbating conflicts.

theories.evidence: Theoretical framework supported by examples such as sexual conflict in Drosophila, cancer cell heterogeneity, host-parasite interactions; references to empirical data on miRNA roles in these contexts; evolutionary biology principles.
theories.criteria_reasoning: This hypothesis integrates evolutionary theory with molecular mechanisms of gene regulation to explain aging-related processes caused by conflict-induced gene expression perturbations, fulfilling the criteria of a general, causal aging theory.
